items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Sunday 06/11/2022, is forecast to be a showery day but the lake level at the Lodore gauge is expected to remain relatively constant. Further rain is forecast over this afternoon and into Monday 07/11/2022 and we expect the lake to start to rise from tomorrow morning. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Flooding is possible at The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall from 03:30am and 06:30am on Monday 07/11/2022 due to strong southerly winds and large onshore waves. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Spring tides are from Monday 07/11/2022 to Wednesday 09/11/2022 and may result in further alerts being issued. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen again on the Upper Wey at Standford as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today 06/11/22.
The forecast for today is for showers, therefore we expect levels to remain high for today.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 06/11/22, or if the situation changes.

Heavy rain has fallen over west London today, Sunday 6 November. 
River levels on the River Pinn are high in the Uxbridge area. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
Further heavy showers are possible this afternoon and this is likely to keep the river levels high.  River levels in Pinner and Hillingdon are also likely to rise again. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen again on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today 06/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
The forecast for today is for showers therefore we expect levels to fall but remain above the threshold for flood alert.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 06/11/22, or if the situation changes.

The River Uck is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 20mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted. From 09:30 today (Sunday 06/11/2022) flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Minor flood impacts could affect the Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage and Bell Walk, Uckfield. From 12:00 (06/11/2022) flood water could approach properties at Isfield Mill and Isfield Bridge. A further 20mm of rain is forecast before midday. The river should begin to fall around 17:00 in Buxted, and 23:00 in Isfield, but will be higher than normal until midweek. We think the river will peak a little lower than on Thursday. Unsettled conditions could continue into Monday (07/11/2022) and Tuesday (08/11/2022), with up to 25mm of rain possible. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/11/2022.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over North London and Hertfordshire today, Sunday 6th November. 

River levels are rising in the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt and Tottenham areas. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible this afternoon and evening. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 

Further heavy rain is possible this afternoon. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over south Hertfordshire this morning, Sunday 6th November. River levels on the Upper River Colne and other rivers and streams in the area are rising, particularly in Colney Heath.  

There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. However, property flooding is not currently expected.

Rivers are likely to stay high for much of the day, with further heavy showers possible. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated at 8pm or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brent from Hendon to Brentford

floodArea.county: Barnet, Brent, Ealing, Greater London, Hounslow

items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over London today, Sunday 6 November. 
River levels in the River Brent in the Greenford area are rising. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
Further heavy showers are possible through the day, with the river remaining high. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are rising at Forest Row, Summerford Bridge, near Withyham and at Colliers land Bridge near Ashurst. The internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst and Penshurst and around Balls Green at Ashurst. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 15mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold. From 11:30 06/11/2022 flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. A further 15mm of rain is expected by midday Sunday. More showers are possible Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 02:00 07/11/2022 but will be higher than normal until midweek. We think the river will peak a little lower than Thursday. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. 33mm of rainfall has been recorded at Wroxall in the last 24 hours. Following on from this week’s earlier rain, this is a significant amount. From 14:00 (06/11/22), the river will come out of bank at Whitwell High Street and Langbridge. It will restrict access to Horringford and be close to the top of the bank at Alverstone. The river will currently be flooding Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Further rain (up to 14mm) is forecast today (06/11/22). At Alverstone, the river won’t peak until late this evening, and could potentially flood properties before this time. At Sandown, the river will not peak until tomorrow morning (07/11/22). We’ve altered Bembridge sluice so that more water flows to sea in between high tides. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you live near the river, please take action to protect your property. This message will be updated at 17:00 on Sunday 06/11/22, or sooner if we think property flooding will occur.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further heavy rain is forecast tomorrow morning, and afternoon which may result in levels on the River Blackwater rising again in the Farnborough,Camberley and Swallowfield areas.
We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

The River Ouse is rising again, following 20mm of rain in the last 24 hours. Another 15mm of rain is forecast before midday Sunday. From 13:00 06/11/2022 flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach the Anchor Inn and properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills Road could be impassable. Currently only minimal or minor flood impacts are expected upstream of Barcombe, with flood water potentially affecting fields, gardens and rural roads near and including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. More showers are possible Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 07:00 07/11/2022 in Barcombe, but could be higher than normal until midweek. We think the river will peak a little lower than Thursday. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 20:00 06/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours and into this afternoon, Sunday 6th November. River levels are expected to continue to rise in response to further rain today, but then fall once the rain has passed. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas around Haverhill, Clare and Sudbury, including Kedington, Sturmer, Steeple Bumpstead, Cavendish, Bridge Street and Long Melford. The weather forecast is for further outbreaks of rain through today, and then light showers over the coming few days. The forecast will remain unsettled over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, Sunday 6th November.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising. In the last 24 hours, 20mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech and another 15mm of rain is forecast before midday Sunday. From 08:00 06/11/2022, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From 11:00 06/11/2022 flood impacts could also affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. From 15:00 06/11/2022 minor flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. More showers are possible Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall around 21:00 06/11/2022 in Hellingly and Monday morning in Alfriston, but will be higher than normal until midweek. We think the river will peak a little lower than Thursday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 06/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are now rising gradually at all locations in the Rother valley. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the river Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. We are ready to use the flood defence scheme at Robertsbridge if required. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Leatherhead and Cobham areas. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains for today 06/11/2022.
Further rainfall is expected today and overnight into Monday 07/11/2022.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 07/11/2022.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely over the next few hours of today, Sunday 6th November. River levels are expected to continue to rise in response to further rain today, but then fall once the rain has passed. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The weather forecast is for further outbreaks of rain through today, and then light showers over the coming few days. The forecast remains unsettled over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Monday 7th November.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. River levels are rising at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are rising gently in Edenbridge, Hever and at Vexour and are forecast to rise in the Lingfield and Haxted Mill areas. Minor flood impacts are expected. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Further heavy rain is forecast today, Sunday 6 November 2022 through to Monday 7 November 2022. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams are still higher than normal, but significantly lower than Sunday morning. Further heavy showers are possible Sunday afternoon, and through Monday and Tuesday too. The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams will rise again following rainfall. Minor flood impacts could still return to Meadow Drive, Bridge Road, West Common Road, Hickmans Lane and Blackthorns this afternoon, while river levels are elevated. However, with less rain currently in the forecast than was measured earlier, we believe river levels should not rise as high as they have been Sunday morning. We'll review this Flood Alert Sunday evening 06/11/2022, when there should be less flood risk. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are routinely clearing debris from grilles through Lindfield, including the Builders Centre and Witch Inn, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have increased in Cranleigh on the Littlemead Brook Waters as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today 06/11/22.
The forecast for today is for showers, therefore we expect levels to remain high for today.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 06/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Ravensbourne area in the London Boroughs of Lewisham, Bromley, Greenwich and Croydon
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Lewisham

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads, low lying land and gardens close to the river Ravensbourne is expected between 11:00 am and 17:00 pm today, 06/11/22. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point but we will update this message as the situation changes. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 8/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and clearing trash screens.
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ingrebourne at Harold Park and Hornchurch
items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over London this morning, Sunday 6th November. Levels in the River Ingrebourne are rising in the Harold Park and Hornchurch areas. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

Further heavy rain is possible through the day. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 

We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 3:00 pm today until the early hours of tomorrow morning. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 36 hours until the evening of Monday 7/11/22.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 8/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the river. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 30mm of rain has been recorded at Liss. This is a lot in a short period. From 18:00 06/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham as well as Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. From 15:00 06/11/2022 river levels will be high and close to the road at The Wharf, Midhurst. Properties on the Lod could also be affected, including near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and at Halfway Bridge. Only minimal impacts are currently expected between Liss and Stedham. More showers are possible Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 05:00 07/11/2022 at Lodsbridge near Selham but will be higher than normal until midweek. River levels are expected to peak higher than Thursday. Early actions to reduce potential impacts with property flood resilience at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022

The Langney Haven is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 40mm of rain has been recorded at Folkington. Which is a lot in a short period. From 14:00 06/11/2022, flooding could affect gardens of Langney Green, and potentially approaching properties at Langney Green too. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park could also be affected. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but another 10mm of rain could fall in showers Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 Sunday 06/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until at least midweek. River levels could end up a little higher than on Friday. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. In the last 24 hours 25mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill, which is a lot in a short period. From 15:30 06/11/2022, flooding will affect fields, Crowhurst recreation ground and rural roads. It is possible, but currently thought unlikely that flood water could approach a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but another 10mm of rain could fall in showers Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 06/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Monday afternoon. River levels could end up a little higher than Thursday and Friday. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.
